metadata.case_name: Sales Tax Officer, Banaras & Ors. v. Respondent Firm

facts.text: The respondent is a firm registered under the Indian Partnership Act dealing in Bullion, Gold and Silver ornaments and forward contracts in Silver Bullion at Banaras in the State of Uttar Pradesh.
For the assessment years 1948-49, 1949-50 and 1950-51 the Sales Tax Officer, Banaras (appellant No. 1) assessed the respondent to U. P. Sales Tax on its forward transactions in Silver Bullion.

The respondent had deposited the sums of Rs. 150-12-0, Rs. 470-0-0 and Rs. 741-0-0 for the said three years which sums were appropriated towards the payment of the sales tax liability under assessment orders dated May 31, 1949, October 30, 1950 and August 22, 1951.
The levy of sales tax on forward transactions was held to be ultra vires by the High Court of Allahabad on February 27, 1952, in Messrs. Budh Prakash Jai Prakash v. Sales Tax Officer, Kanpur.
The respondent by letter dated July 8, 1952, asked for a refund of the amounts of sales tax paid.
The Commissioner of Sales Tax, U. P. (appellant No. 2) by letter dated July 19, 1952, refused to refund the same.

The respondent filed Civil Misc. Writ Petition No. 355 of 1952 under Art. 226 of the Constitution asking for writ of certiorari quashing the three assessment orders and writ of mandamus for refund of Rs. 1,365-12-0.
The Allahabad High Court judgment in Budh Prakash was confirmed by Supreme Court on May 3, 1954, in Sales Tax Officer, Pilibhit v. Budh Prakash Jai Prakash.
Chaturvedi J. by order dated November 30, 1954, quashed the assessment orders insofar as they related to forward contracts and issued mandamus directing refund.
Appellants filed Special Appeal No. 18 of 1955, dismissed by Division Bench on December 1, 1955, holding s. 72 Indian Contract Act applied.
High Court granted certificate under Art. 133(1)(b) on July 30, 1956, on undertaking by Advocate-General to pay costs.

legal_issues.text: Whether s. 72 of the Indian Contract Act applies to the facts of the present case, particularly to money paid under a mistake of law (sales tax on forward transactions held ultra vires).

petitioner_arguments.text: The respondent ought to have followed procedure of appeal/revision under U.P. Sales Tax Act, not writ petition under Art. 226.
Money paid under mistake of law is irrecoverable, analogous to English, American, Australian law.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s. 72 Indian Contract Act; English authorities like Rogers v. Ingham

petitioner_arguments.text: Payments were voluntary without protest, in discharge of tax liability; money spent by State, estoppel applies.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s. 72 Indian Contract Act (observations on circumstances disentitling recovery)

respondent_arguments.text: Entitled to refund under s. 72 Indian Contract Act as payments made under mistake of law.

court_reasoning.text: s. 72 applies without distinction between mistake of law or fact; plain terms prevail over English law analogies.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Term 'mistake' in s. 72 comprises mistake of law as well as fact.

court_reasoning.text: Follows Privy Council in Shiba Prasad Singh v. Srish Chandra Nandi: mistake of law covered if money not due; no conflict with s. 21/22.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Payment by mistake in s. 72 refers to payment not legally due.

court_reasoning.text: Procedural contentions not available due to Advocate-General's categorical statements in High Court.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No point taken earlier on appeal/revision or writ maintainability.

court_reasoning.text: Voluntary payments without protest do not disentitle recovery if under mistake of law; no estoppel as both parties mistaken.
court_reasoning.key_observation: State spent money irrelevant; no equitable considerations override clear s. 72.

court_reasoning.text: Tax payments treated same as others under s. 72; no distinction for taxes.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Cannot add words like 'otherwise than by way of taxes' to s. 72.

holdings.text: s. 72 Indian Contract Act entitles recovery of money paid under mistake of law if not legally due, irrespective of voluntary nature or tax character, subject to estoppel etc. (none here).

precedents_cited.case_name: Messrs. Budh Prakash Jai Prakash v. Sales Tax Officer, Kanpur
precedents_cited.relevance: Held levy on forward transactions ultra vires.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sales Tax Officer, Pilibhit v. Budh Prakash Jai Prakash
precedents_cited.relevance: Confirmed Allahabad HC on ultra vires levy.

precedents_cited.case_name: Shiba Prasad Singh v. Srish Chandra Nundi
precedents_cited.relevance: s. 72 covers mistake of law; resolved conflict on interpretation.
Interpret Contract Act plainly; no equity against statute.

precedents_cited.case_name: Satyabrata Ghose v. Mugneeram Bangur Co.
precedents_cited.relevance: Contract Act exhaustive; no import English law.

precedents_cited.case_name: Jagdish Prasad Pannalal v. Produce Exchange Corporation Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Mistake in s. 72 includes law; distinguished from s. 21.

precedents_cited.case_name: Wolf Sons v. Dadyba Khimji Co.
precedents_cited.relevance: Held s. 72 excludes mistake of law; overruled by PC.

precedents_cited.case_name: Appavoo Chettiar v. S. I. Ry. Co.
precedents_cited.relevance: Limited mistake to fact; fallacious per PC.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Contract Act, 1872
statutes_cited.relevance: s.72 mandates repayment of money paid by mistake (law or fact) or coercion; no conflict with ss.21/22.

statutes_cited.name: U.P. Sales Tax Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Assessments under it on forward transactions ultra vires; payments thereunder recoverable under s.72.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Writ petition filed under Art.226; certificate under Art.133.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed confirming High Court order quashing assessments on forward transactions and directing refund of Rs. 1,365-12-0 with costs; State to repay under s.72 Indian Contract Act.
outcome.relief_granted: Refund of sales tax amounts paid on forward transactions; costs to respondent.
outcome.costs: Appeal dismissed with costs; State undertook to pay costs as taxed.

key_quotes.text: "A person to whom money has been paid, or anything delivered by mistake or under coercion, must repay or return it."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Text of s.72 Indian Contract Act central to holding.

key_quotes.text: The term mistake has been used without any qualification or limitation whatever and comprises within its scope a mistake of law as well as a mistake of fact.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects distinction between mistake of law and fact.

key_quotes.text: Payment by mistake in s. 72 must refer to a payment which was not legally due and which could not have been enforced the mistake is thinking that the money paid was due when, in fact, it was not due.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains scope per Privy Council; applies to tax payments.

key_quotes.text: Merely because the State of U. P. had not retained the monies paid by the respondent but had spent them away in the ordinary course of the business of the State would not make any difference.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects estoppel or change of position by recipient.
